questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image
questions.solution:
Adenoid facies: It refers to the facial appearance of individuals with chronic adenoid hypertrophy. It is characterized by an open-mouthed expression, elongated face, high arched palate, and prominent incisors. Chronic adenoid hypertrophy can result in nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and changes in facial structure, leading to the characteristic appearance known as adenoid facies.

B. Goldenhar syndrome: Goldenhar syndrome, also known as oculo-auriculo-vertebral spectrum (OAVS), is a congenital condition characterized by facial and ear anomalies, vertebral defects, and eye abnormalities. It typically involves asymmetry of the face, but it is not represented by the image shown.

C. Horse face deformity is a term used to describe a facial appearance that is characterized by a long face, a high forehead, and a prominent nose. It is not caused by adenoid hypertrophy.

D. Frog face deformity is a term used to describe a facial appearance that is characterized by a short face, a depressed nasal bridge, and a receding chin. It is not caused by adenoid hypertrophy.

choices.text: Allergic mucin discharge showing fungal hyphae

questions.text: Which is not a major criteria for the diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis?
questions.solution:
The 5 major criteria for the Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis are:

  1. Evidence of type I IgE-mediated hypersensitivity
  2. Nasal polyposis
  3. Characteristic CT findings
  4. Eosinophilic mucus
  5. Positive fungal smear

questions.text: Which is the most common source of bleeding during tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Paratonsillar vein: After tonsillectomy (tonsil surgery), postoperative bleeding can occur, and the bleeding source is commonly the paratonsillar vein (peritonsillar vein). The paratonsillar vein is located near the tonsils and can be a site of bleeding following tonsil surgery. Post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage is a known complication, and the bleeding often originates from this vein.

B. External palatine vein: This is a less likely source of bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils.

C. Ascending pharyngeal artery: This is less likely to cause bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils and is a larger vessel.

D. Facial artery: This is less likely to cause bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils and is a larger vessel.

questions.text: What is the most common salivary gland tumor?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign salivary gland tumor, also known as a mixed tumor. It can occur in both major and minor salivary glands. Pleomorphic adenoma is composed of a mixture of different cell types, including epithelial and myoepithelial cells, and it is encapsulated.

A. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a malignant tumor derived from glandular epithelial tissue. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma and represents a cancerous (malignant) tumor.

C. Mucoepidermoid tumor: Mucoepidermoid tumor is a common malignant salivary gland tumor that includes both mucus-secreting and squamous cells. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

D. Basal cell carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from basal cells in the epidermis.
